elements.content: Development of chiral metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) for circularly polarized luminescence (CPL) is a challenging but important task. In this work, we report a first example of azapyrene-based chiral MOF thin films [Zn2Cam2DAP] n grown on functionalized substrates (named SURchirMOF-4) for CPL property. By using a liquid-phase epitaxial layer-by-layer method, the resulted SURchirMOF-4 was constructed from chiral camphoric acid and 2,7-diazapyrene ligand, which has high orientation and homogeneity. The circular dichroism, CPL, and enantioselective adsorption results show that SURchirMOF-4 has strong chirality and CPL property as well as good enantioselective adsorption toward enantiomers of methyl-lactate. The synthesis of azapyrene-based chiral MOF thin films not only represents an ideal model for studying the enantioselective adsorption, but also will be a valuable approach for development of the chiral thin film exhibiting CPL property.
elements.clean_text: Development of chiral metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) for circularly polarized luminescence (CPL) is a challenging but important task. In this work, we report a first example of azapyrene-based chiral MOF thin films [Zn2Cam2DAP] n  grown on functionalized substrates (named SURchirMOF-4) for CPL property. By using a liquid-phase epitaxial layer-by-layer method, the resulted SURchirMOF-4 was constructed from chiral camphoric acid and 2,7-diazapyrene ligand, which has high orientation and homogeneity. The circular dichroism, CPL, and enantioselective adsorption results show that SURchirMOF-4 has strong chirality and CPL property as well as good enantioselective adsorption toward enantiomers of methyl-lactate. The synthesis of azapyrene-based chiral MOF thin films not only represents an ideal model for studying the enantioselective adsorption, but also will be a valuable approach for development of the chiral thin film exhibiting CPL property.

elements.content: The synthesis and applications of chiral materials have been rapidly expanding because of their application of pharmaceutics, agriculture, biology, and chemical engineering. As a new class of chiral materials, chiral metal–organic frameworks (chirMOFs) combining the features of chirality and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted great attention because of their fascinating potential applications in enantiomer recognition, enantioselective adsorption/separation, asymmetric catalysis, and nonlinear optics. However, the form of MOF thin films or membranes is required for some practical applications. So far, different kinds of techniques for MOF thin films or membrane preparation have been developed for separators, devices, and sensors. Particularly, the liquid-phase epitaxy (LPE) layer-by-layer approach is a good candidate method for MOF thin film preparation (also known as SURMOFs), which is assembled by sequentially immersing the functionalized substrate into the metal salts and organic ligands solutions. The sample is cleaned with solvent for removing the uncoordinated precursors after each immersion step. Such MOF thin films exhibit remarkable advantages, such as controllable growth orientation, tunable thickness, and high homogeneity, providing a promising thin film model for the study in coordination chemistry and growth mechanism as well as diffusion behavior of guest species. However, the preparation and application of chiral SURMOFs is still a challenging task but very important for chiral chemistry in the thin film system. In previous work, homochiral SURMOFs M2Cam2L (M = Zn or Cu; Cam = camphoric acid; L = diazabicyclo[2.2.2]-octane (dabco), 4,4-bipyridyl (bipy) and 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)­benzene (bipyb)) constructed from camphoric acid and different pillared ligands (dabco, bipy and bipyb) have been studied for enanotioselective adsorption/adsorption by using quartz-crystal microbalance (QCM) and gas chromatography techniques. Therefore, exploring new chiral SURMOFs for various applications is extremely urgent.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The synthesis and applications of chiral materials have been rapidly expanding because of their application of pharmaceutics, agriculture, biology, and chemical engineering. As a new class of chiral materials, chiral metal-organic frameworks (chirMOFs) combining the features of chirality and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted great attention because of their fascinating potential applications in enantiomer recognition, enantioselective adsorption/separation, asymmetric catalysis, and nonlinear optics. However, the form of MOF thin films or membranes is required for some practical applications. So far, different kinds of techniques for MOF thin films or membrane preparation have been developed for separators, devices, and sensors. Particularly, the liquid-phase epitaxy (LPE) layer-by-layer approach is a good candidate method for MOF thin film preparation (also known as SURMOFs), which is assembled by sequentially immersing the functionalized substrate into the metal salts and organic ligands solutions. The sample is cleaned with solvent for removing the uncoordinated precursors after each immersion step. Such MOF thin films exhibit remarkable advantages, such as controllable growth orientation, tunable thickness, and high homogeneity, providing a promising thin film model for the study in coordination chemistry and growth mechanism as well as diffusion behavior of guest species. However, the preparation and application of chiral SURMOFs is still a challenging task but very important for chiral chemistry in the thin film system. In previous work, homochiral SURMOFs M2Cam2L (M = Zn or Cu; Cam = camphoric acid; L = diazabicyclo[2.2.2]-octane (dabco), 4,4-bipyridyl (bipy) and 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene (bipyb)) constructed from camphoric acid and different pillared ligands (dabco, bipy and bipyb) have been studied for enanotioselective adsorption/adsorption by using quartz-crystal microbalance (QCM) and gas chromatography techniques. Therefore, exploring new chiral SURMOFs for various applications is extremely urgent.

elements.content: On the other hand, recently, the development of chiral materials exhibiting circularly polarized luminescence (CPL) has attracted great interest owing to their potential applications in the fields of optical displays, information transmission/storage, photoelectric devices, and chiral sensors. So far, chiral materials constructed from inorganic oxides, organic molecules, polymers, supermoleculars, and the related chiral thin films have been reported for CPL properties. However, developing of chiral MOF thin films for CPL has not been reported, but it is a challenging and important task.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, recently, the development of chiral materials exhibiting circularly polarized luminescence (CPL) has attracted great interest owing to their potential applications in the fields of optical displays, information transmission/storage, photoelectric devices, and chiral sensors. So far, chiral materials constructed from inorganic oxides, organic molecules, polymers, supermoleculars, and the related chiral thin films have been reported for CPL properties. However, developing of chiral MOF thin films for CPL has not been reported, but it is a challenging and important task.

elements.content: For preparing MOF thin films with CPL, in this work, the camphoric acid (H2Cam) is chosen as the chiral ligand, and a pyrene-contained molecule is synthesized as the luminescence auxiliary ligand because pyrene-based materials showed fascinating fluorescent properties. Herein, 2,7-diazapyrene (DAP) with two pyridine groups provides an ideal candidate for constructing a pillar-layered MOF with H2Cam. The synthesis process of DAP with three high-yield steps is shown in a. First, the concentrated ammonium hydroxide solution reacts with the commercially available 1,4,5,8-naphthalene tetracarboxylic dianhydride to form 1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxylic diimide (1). Then, the obtained compound reacts with borane under refluxing tetrahydrofuran to produce 1,2,3,6,7,8-hexahydro-2,7-diazapyrene (2). Afterward, DAP (3) can be given by oxidization with manganese dioxide under refluxing benzene. The photoluminescence and UV–vis spectra show that DAP possesses intense luminescence property (Figures S1–S3), which is a good candidate for assembling CPL-based MOF.
elements.clean_text: For preparing MOF thin films with CPL, in this work, the camphoric acid (H2Cam) is chosen as the chiral ligand, and a pyrene-contained molecule is synthesized as the luminescence auxiliary ligand because pyrene-based materials showed fascinating fluorescent properties. Herein, 2,7-diazapyrene (DAP) with two pyridine groups provides an ideal candidate for constructing a pillar-layered MOF with H2Cam. The synthesis process of DAP with three high-yield steps is shown in a. First, the concentrated ammonium hydroxide solution reacts with the commercially available 1,4,5,8-naphthalene tetracarboxylic dianhydride to form 1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxylic diimide (1). Then, the obtained compound reacts with borane under refluxing tetrahydrofuran to produce 1,2,3,6,7,8-hexahydro-2,7-diazapyrene (2). Afterward, DAP (3) can be given by oxidization with manganese dioxide under refluxing benzene. The photoluminescence and UV-vis spectra show that DAP possesses intense luminescence property (Figures S1-S3), which is a good candidate for assembling CPL-based MOF.

elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Synthesis Process of DAP; (b) Schematic Drawing of SURchirMOF [Zn2Cam2DAP] n  Grown on the Substrate Surface by a LPE Layer-by-Layer Approach along [001]

elements.content: Previous reports reveal that the carboxylate- and pyridine-based ligands can be used to prepare the pillar-layered MOF thin films by using a liquid-phase epitaxial layer-by-layer approach, such as [M2(Cam)2dabo] n , [M2(Cam)2bipy] n , [M2(Cam)2bibipy] n , [M2(bdc)2dabo] n , and [M2(bdc)2bipy] n . Herein, a new pair of enantiopure chiral MOF thin films [Zn2(Cam)2DAP] n are successfully prepared on OH-terminated substrates by an LPE layer-by-layer method (named SURchirMOF-4), displaying a [001]-orientated MOF thin film. The structure of [Zn2(Cam)2DAP] n is simulated from the [Zn2(Cam)2bipy] n reported in the literature. The quartz glass was used as the substrate for examining the chirality and CPL property. The gas-phase QCM uptakes of enantiomers d- and l-methyl-lactate for d/l-SURchirMOF-4 demonstrate a good enantioselective adsorption (selectivity of ∼26 and 28% for d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 respectively). Furthermore, the circular dichroism (CD) and CPL show that SURchirMOF-4 has a strong and opposite CD and CPL signal in d- and l-SURchirMOF-4. The presented studies indicate that such a porous MOF thin film not only provides an ideal model for studying the enantioselective adsorption, but also offers a valuable guidance for development of the chiral thin film exhibiting CPL property.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Previous reports reveal that the carboxylate- and pyridine-based ligands can be used to prepare the pillar-layered MOF thin films by using a liquid-phase epitaxial layer-by-layer approach, such as [M2(Cam)2dabo] n , [M2(Cam)2bipy] n , [M2(Cam)2bibipy] n , [M2(bdc)2dabo] n , and [M2(bdc)2bipy] n . Herein, a new pair of enantiopure chiral MOF thin films [Zn2(Cam)2DAP] n  are successfully prepared on OH-terminated substrates by an LPE layer-by-layer method (named SURchirMOF-4), displaying a [001]-orientated MOF thin film. The structure of [Zn2(Cam)2DAP] n  is simulated from the [Zn2(Cam)2bipy] n  reported in the literature. The quartz glass was used as the substrate for examining the chirality and CPL property. The gas-phase QCM uptakes of enantiomers d- and l-methyl-lactate for d/l-SURchirMOF-4 demonstrate a good enantioselective adsorption (selectivity of ~26 and 28% for d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 respectively). Furthermore, the circular dichroism (CD) and CPL show that SURchirMOF-4 has a strong and opposite CD and CPL signal in d- and l-SURchirMOF-4. The presented studies indicate that such a porous MOF thin film not only provides an ideal model for studying the enantioselective adsorption, but also offers a valuable guidance for development of the chiral thin film exhibiting CPL property.

elements.content: In the structure of pillar-layered homochiral MOF [Zn2Cam2DAP] n , [Zn2Cam2] n serves as the layer, while DAP acts as the pillar. In this work, homochiral SURMOF [Zn2Cam2DAP] n (SURchirMOF-4) was grown on hydroxyl-functionalized quartz glass adopting the LPE pump method (b). During the epitaxial growth process, the DAP coordinates to the axial positions in zinc complexes [Zn2 d/lCam2], perpendicular to the chiral [Zn2 d/lCam2] layers, resulting in a [001]-direction for d/l-SURchirMOF-4, which is similar to the reported isostructural [Zn2Cam2L] n thin films. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern (a) showed two diffraction peaks at 6.30 and 12.6° corresponding to the (001) and (002) planes in the obtained SURchirMOF-4 on OH-functionalized substrates, which clearly demonstrated that a preferentially [001]-oriented crystal thin film was formed. The infrared reflection–absorption spectroscopy (IRRAS) spectrum of d/l-SURchirMOF-4 has an asymmetric vibration at ∼1690 cm–1 because the Zn–Zn axis was parallel to the substrate surface. The surface morphology of SURchirMOF-4 grown on the OH-functionalized gold substrate was observed from scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images in c,d and S4 as well as the atomic force microscopy (AFM) image (Figure S5), showing a highly homogeneous crystallite coating.
elements.clean_text: In the structure of pillar-layered homochiral MOF [Zn2Cam2DAP] n , [Zn2Cam2] n  serves as the layer, while DAP acts as the pillar. In this work, homochiral SURMOF [Zn2Cam2DAP] n  (SURchirMOF-4) was grown on hydroxyl-functionalized quartz glass adopting the LPE pump method (b). During the epitaxial growth process, the DAP coordinates to the axial positions in zinc complexes [Zn2 d/lCam2], perpendicular to the chiral [Zn2 d/lCam2] layers, resulting in a [001]-direction for d/l-SURchirMOF-4, which is similar to the reported isostructural [Zn2Cam2L] n  thin films. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern (a) showed two diffraction peaks at 6.30 and 12.6° corresponding to the (001) and (002) planes in the obtained SURchirMOF-4 on OH-functionalized substrates, which clearly demonstrated that a preferentially [001]-oriented crystal thin film was formed. The infrared reflection-absorption spectroscopy (IRRAS) spectrum of d/l-SURchirMOF-4 has an asymmetric vibration at ~1690 cm-1 because the Zn-Zn axis was parallel to the substrate surface. The surface morphology of SURchirMOF-4 grown on the OH-functionalized gold substrate was observed from scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images in c,d and S4 as well as the atomic force microscopy (AFM) image (Figure S5), showing a highly homogeneous crystallite coating.

elements.content: XRD (a) and infrared reflection adsorption IR spectroscopy (b) of [Zn2 d/lCam2DAP] n (d/l-SURchirMOF-4) grown on hydroxyl-functionalized glass substrate; (c,d) SEM images of d-SURchirMOF-4 grown on the substrate surface.
elements.clean_text: 1  XRD (a) and infrared reflection adsorption IR spectroscopy (b) of [Zn2 d/lCam2DAP] n  (d/l-SURchirMOF-4) grown on hydroxyl-functionalized glass substrate; (c,d) SEM images of d-SURchirMOF-4 grown on the substrate surface.

elements.content: The optical activity properties of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses (a) were further studied at room temperature. The photoluminescence (b and S6) showed that SURchirMOF-4 displayed a similar intense fluorescence with the maximum emissions at 390, 410, and 432 nm when it was excited at 365 nm, which were similar to the UV–vis absorption spectra (Figures S7 and S8). The CD data recorded for SURchirMOFs [Zn2(Dcam)2DAP] n (d-SURchirMOF-4) and [Zn2(Lcam)2DAP] n (l-SURchirMOF-4) were shown in c. The CD spectra showed four negative bands at 243, 271, 335, and 395 nm and two positive bands at 249 and 307 nm for d-SURchirMOF-4 fabricated exclusively with enantiopure Dcam and DAP. Moreover, the enantiomeric pairs show dichroic absorption of an equal in magnitude but opposite signal.
elements.clean_text: The optical activity properties of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses (a) were further studied at room temperature. The photoluminescence (b and S6) showed that SURchirMOF-4 displayed a similar intense fluorescence with the maximum emissions at 390, 410, and 432 nm when it was excited at 365 nm, which were similar to the UV-vis absorption spectra (Figures S7 and S8). The CD data recorded for SURchirMOFs [Zn2(Dcam)2DAP] n  (d-SURchirMOF-4) and [Zn2(Lcam)2DAP] n  (l-SURchirMOF-4) were shown in c. The CD spectra showed four negative bands at 243, 271, 335, and 395 nm and two positive bands at 249 and 307 nm for d-SURchirMOF-4 fabricated exclusively with enantiopure Dcam and DAP. Moreover, the enantiomeric pairs show dichroic absorption of an equal in magnitude but opposite signal.

elements.content: (a) Photoimages of quartz glass, d- and l-SURMOF-4 grown on quartz glass under light (left) and 365 nm irradiation (right); the photoluminescent emission spectra (b) and CD spectra (c) of d- and l-SURMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Photoimages of quartz glass, d- and l-SURMOF-4 grown on quartz glass under light (left) and 365 nm irradiation (right); the photoluminescent emission spectra (b) and CD spectra (c) of d- and l-SURMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses.

elements.content: CPL is a unique property used to evaluate the chirality of chiral materials. Recently, scientists have reported a ligand-exchange approach to form a chiral zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) powder for CPL. However, such a ligand-exchange approach usually cannot exchange the ligand completely and the powder form of ZIF is also not convenient in the practical CPL application. Therefore, the in-situ epitaxial growth of MOF thin films for CPL is a promising material for CPL application. Herein, we investigate the CPL of the d- and l-SURMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses. Different handedness CPL signals () could be observed and the relative CPL signals were at ∼330 nm. The results display that the CPL signals of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 were opposite. The corresponding g lum factors (Figure S9) were ∼3 × 10–3 and −8 × 10–3 for d- and l-SURchirMOF-4, respectively.
elements.clean_text: CPL is a unique property used to evaluate the chirality of chiral materials. Recently, scientists have reported a ligand-exchange approach to form a chiral zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) powder for CPL. However, such a ligand-exchange approach usually cannot exchange the ligand completely and the powder form of ZIF is also not convenient in the practical CPL application. Therefore, the in-situ epitaxial growth of MOF thin films for CPL is a promising material for CPL application. Herein, we investigate the CPL of the d- and l-SURMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses. Different handedness CPL signals () could be observed and the relative CPL signals were at ~330 nm. The results display that the CPL signals of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 were opposite. The corresponding g lum factors (Figure S9) were ~3 × 10-3 and -8 × 10-3 for d- and l-SURchirMOF-4, respectively.

elements.content: CPL spectra of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4.
elements.clean_text: 3  CPL spectra of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4.

elements.content: To further study the chiral recognition of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4, the adsorption performance of enantiomers can be carried out in this work. A gas phase QCM technology has been developed for investigating the enantioselectivity of homochiral MOF thin films, which can monitor mass changes with nanogram by detecting the change of resonance frequency. The d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 thin films were grown on Au-coated QCM sensors. The thickness of d-SURchirMOF-4 was measured by cross-section SEM and was about 320 nm (Figure S10). A pair of enantiomers d- and l-methyl-lactate was selected as the chiral probe molecules for studying their enantioselectivity. The related adsorption amount of d and l-methyl-lactate for d-SURchirMOF-4 and l-SURchirMOF-4 were carried out respectively, which were shown in . The adsorption amount of d- and l-methyl-lactate for d-SURchirMOF-4 was ∼2.08 (M D) and ∼3.54 (M L) μg/cm2, respectively (a). The different adsorption showed an important enantioselective adsorption for one enantiomer methyl-lactate in SURchirMOF-4. When we applied the equation “ee % = (M L – M D)/(M D + M L) × 100” for analyzing the enantioselectivity, the enantioselectivity ee % of SURchirMOF-4 for methyl-lactate was found to be 26%. With the same measurement, the probe enantiomers of d/l-methyl-lactate were used for studying the enantioselective adsorption of l-SURchirMOF-4. The recorded data (b) showed that the adsorption amounts of d- and l-methyl-lactate were ∼3.62 (M D) and ∼2.02 (M L) μg/cm2 for l-SURchirMOF-4, respectively. The related enantioselectivity ee % was 28% after using the same equation, which was the opposite enantioselective adsorption of d-SURchirMOF-4.
elements.clean_text: To further study the chiral recognition of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4, the adsorption performance of enantiomers can be carried out in this work. A gas phase QCM technology has been developed for investigating the enantioselectivity of homochiral MOF thin films, which can monitor mass changes with nanogram by detecting the change of resonance frequency. The d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 thin films were grown on Au-coated QCM sensors. The thickness of d-SURchirMOF-4 was measured by cross-section SEM and was about 320 nm (Figure S10). A pair of enantiomers d- and l-methyl-lactate was selected as the chiral probe molecules for studying their enantioselectivity. The related adsorption amount of d and l-methyl-lactate for d-SURchirMOF-4 and l-SURchirMOF-4 were carried out respectively, which were shown in . The adsorption amount of d- and l-methyl-lactate for d-SURchirMOF-4 was ~2.08 (M D) and ~3.54 (M L) μg/cm2, respectively (a). The different adsorption showed an important enantioselective adsorption for one enantiomer methyl-lactate in SURchirMOF-4. When we applied the equation "ee % = (M L - M D)/(M D + M L) × 100" for analyzing the enantioselectivity, the enantioselectivity ee % of SURchirMOF-4 for methyl-lactate was found to be 26%. With the same measurement, the probe enantiomers of d/l-methyl-lactate were used for studying the enantioselective adsorption of l-SURchirMOF-4. The recorded data (b) showed that the adsorption amounts of d- and l-methyl-lactate were ~3.62 (M D) and ~2.02 (M L) μg/cm2 for l-SURchirMOF-4, respectively. The related enantioselectivity ee % was 28% after using the same equation, which was the opposite enantioselective adsorption of d-SURchirMOF-4.

elements.content: Mass uptake of the enantiomers d- and l-methyl lactate in d- (a) and l- (b) SURchirMOF-4 using by a gas phase QCM technique.
elements.clean_text: 4  Mass uptake of the enantiomers d- and l-methyl lactate in d- (a) and l- (b) SURchirMOF-4 using by a gas phase QCM technique.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized new homochiral MOF thin films [Zn2Cam2DAP] n (named SURchirMOF-4) with a homogeneous surface and [001]-orientation from camphoric acid (H2Cam) and DAP by using the liquid-phase epitaxial layer-by-layer method. Combining a bifunctional thin film with chirality of ligands H2Cam and luminescence ligand DAP, CD and CPL as well as enantioselective adsorption of the obtained MOF thin films have been studied. The results show that SURchirMOF-4 has strong CPL property and good enantioselective adsorption toward enantiomers d- or l-methyl-lactate. The presented chiral MOF thin films not only provides an ideal model for studying enantioselective adsorption, but also offers a valuable guidance for development of the chiral thin film exhibiting CPL property.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully synthesized new homochiral MOF thin films [Zn2Cam2DAP] n  (named SURchirMOF-4) with a homogeneous surface and [001]-orientation from camphoric acid (H2Cam) and DAP by using the liquid-phase epitaxial layer-by-layer method. Combining a bifunctional thin film with chirality of ligands H2Cam and luminescence ligand DAP, CD and CPL as well as enantioselective adsorption of the obtained MOF thin films have been studied. The results show that SURchirMOF-4 has strong CPL property and good enantioselective adsorption toward enantiomers d- or l-methyl-lactate. The presented chiral MOF thin films not only provides an ideal model for studying enantioselective adsorption, but also offers a valuable guidance for development of the chiral thin film exhibiting CPL property.

elements.content: All solvents and reagents used were commercially available. Powder XRD was carried out using a MiniFlex2 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.1542 nm) in the 2θ range of 4°–16°. Software JADE 6.5 was used for evaluating the XRD data. The JSM6700 instrument was used for SEM image measurement. The fluorescence emission was measured by an FLS-980 fluorescence spectrometer. AFM was performed on a Bruker FastScan system. The CD spectra were recorded by CD spectrometer MOS-450. Fluorescence and CPL spectra were obtained using F-4500 fluorescence and JASCO CPL-200 spectrophotometers, respectively. The quartz glass substrate was used as the reference of the CD and CPL measurements. The samples were fixed on the instrument directly and perpendicular to the light beam during the measurement. The background spectra from the quartz glass substrates were subtracted to obtain the final processed CD and CPL spectra. UV–vis spectra are measured on a Lambda 900 spectrophotometer. The IRRAS technique was also used for SURMOF characterization by using a Bruker VERTEX 70. Bruker OPUS software version 5.5 was used for evaluating the IR data.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

All solvents and reagents used were commercially available. Powder XRD was carried out using a MiniFlex2 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.1542 nm) in the 2θ range of 4°-16°. Software JADE 6.5 was used for evaluating the XRD data. The JSM6700 instrument was used for SEM image measurement. The fluorescence emission was measured by an FLS-980 fluorescence spectrometer. AFM was performed on a Bruker FastScan system. The CD spectra were recorded by CD spectrometer MOS-450. Fluorescence and CPL spectra were obtained using F-4500 fluorescence and JASCO CPL-200 spectrophotometers, respectively. The quartz glass substrate was used as the reference of the CD and CPL measurements. The samples were fixed on the instrument directly and perpendicular to the light beam during the measurement. The background spectra from the quartz glass substrates were subtracted to obtain the final processed CD and CPL spectra. UV-vis spectra are measured on a Lambda 900 spectrophotometer. The IRRAS technique was also used for SURMOF characterization by using a Bruker VERTEX 70. Bruker OPUS software version 5.5 was used for evaluating the IR data.

elements.content: 1,4,5,8-Naphthalenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (12.5 g, 46.6 mmol) was dissolved in a stirred concentrated ammonium hydroxide (625 mL, 29.5%, w/w) aqueous solution. Then, the mixture was stirred for 6 h under nitrogen and a pale yellow product diimide precipitate was obtained after filtering, washing, and drying under vacuum at 60 °C overnight. Yield: 11.9 g (96%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO): δ 12.10 (s, 2H), 8.62 (s, 4H).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1,4,5,8-Naphthalenetetracarboxylic Diimide (1)

1,4,5,8-Naphthalenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (12.5 g, 46.6 mmol) was dissolved in a stirred concentrated ammonium hydroxide (625 mL, 29.5%, w/w) aqueous solution. Then, the mixture was stirred for 6 h under nitrogen and a pale yellow product diimide precipitate was obtained after filtering, washing, and drying under vacuum at 60 °C overnight. Yield: 11.9 g (96%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO): δ 12.10 (s, 2H), 8.62 (s, 4H).

elements.content: Diimide (2 g, 7.52 mmol) and anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF; 40 mL) was added in a three-neck flask (250 mL) with stirring and refluxing under a nitrogen atmosphere. Then, the suspension was added slowly via the dropping BH3-THF (80 mL, 1 M) solution. The obtained mixture was then refluxed for 60 h. During that time, there was hydrogen evolution and the color changed to orange. The HCl solution (8 mL, 6 M) was added to the mixture and refluxed for quenching the reaction after cooling 0 °C. Caution: at that time, the mixture may foam strongly, so the stirring must be vigorous. The liquid was evaporated, and the residue was cooled to 0 °C. Afterward, potassium carbonate aqueous saturated solution was added for tuning the pH (>10). The solid was added and dried completely under vacuum at 40 °C. The dry solid was extracted with refluxing benzene in a Soxhlet extractor for a week. After this period, the benzene was removed in vacuo to yield 1.22 g (77%) of pure diamine which can be recrystallized from benzene to give off-white powder. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.11 (s, 4H), 4.28 (s, 8H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ 132.90, 127.90, 120.34, 48.90.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1,2,3,6,7,8-Hexahydro-2,7-diazapyrene (2)

Diimide (2 g, 7.52 mmol) and anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF; 40 mL) was added in a three-neck flask (250 mL) with stirring and refluxing under a nitrogen atmosphere. Then, the suspension was added slowly via the dropping BH3-THF (80 mL, 1 M) solution. The obtained mixture was then refluxed for 60 h. During that time, there was hydrogen evolution and the color changed to orange. The HCl solution (8 mL, 6 M) was added to the mixture and refluxed for quenching the reaction after cooling 0 °C. Caution: at that time, the mixture may foam strongly, so the stirring must be vigorous. The liquid was evaporated, and the residue was cooled to 0 °C. Afterward, potassium carbonate aqueous saturated solution was added for tuning the pH (>10). The solid was added and dried completely under vacuum at 40 °C. The dry solid was extracted with refluxing benzene in a Soxhlet extractor for a week. After this period, the benzene was removed in vacuo to yield 1.22 g (77%) of pure diamine which can be recrystallized from benzene to give off-white powder. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.11 (s, 4H), 4.28 (s, 8H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ 132.90, 127.90, 120.34, 48.90.

elements.content: A 500 mL round-bottom flask was charged with benzene (250 mL) and then MnO2 (10 g, 115.02 mmol, activated grade, Aldrich) was added. After the addition, the hot solution was filtered after refluxing for 24 h. The filtered MnO2 was dried under vacuum and subjected to a Soxhlet extraction with the benzene solution of the filtrate for 3 days. After removal of the benzene in vacuo, 0.2 g (21%) of pure diazapyrene was obtained as yellow crystals. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.51 (s, 4H), 8.22 (s, 4H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ 144.36, 125.39, 125.20, 124.8.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of DAP (3)

A 500 mL round-bottom flask was charged with benzene (250 mL) and then MnO2 (10 g, 115.02 mmol, activated grade, Aldrich) was added. After the addition, the hot solution was filtered after refluxing for 24 h. The filtered MnO2 was dried under vacuum and subjected to a Soxhlet extraction with the benzene solution of the filtrate for 3 days. After removal of the benzene in vacuo, 0.2 g (21%) of pure diazapyrene was obtained as yellow crystals. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.51 (s, 4H), 8.22 (s, 4H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ 144.36, 125.39, 125.20, 124.8.

elements.content: The self-assembled OH-functionalized (11-mercapto-1-undecanol) on Au/Si wafer and Au-coated QCM-sensor are prepared for SURMOF preparation. For CD and CPL experiments, [001]-orientated SURchirMOF-4 was prepared on a hydroxyl terminal quartz glass substrate, which is similar to the reported literature, except replacing the new ligand solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of OH-Functionalized Substrates and SURchirMOF-4 [Zn2Cam2DAP] n  

The self-assembled OH-functionalized (11-mercapto-1-undecanol) on Au/Si wafer and Au-coated QCM-sensor are prepared for SURMOF preparation. For CD and CPL experiments, [001]-orientated SURchirMOF-4 was prepared on a hydroxyl terminal quartz glass substrate, which is similar to the reported literature, except replacing the new ligand solutions.

elements.content: A gas-phase QCM with a flow module was used for measuring the adsorption performance of the obtained samples. The setup of the gas-phase QCM and measurements and data evolution were followed according to the previous literature.
elements.clean_text:
QCM Adsorption of SURchirMOF-4

A gas-phase QCM with a flow module was used for measuring the adsorption performance of the obtained samples. The setup of the gas-phase QCM and measurements and data evolution were followed according to the previous literature.

1,4,5,8-Naphthalenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (12.5 g, 46.6 mmol) was dissolved in a stirred concentrated ammonium hydroxide (625 mL, 29.5%, w/w) aqueous solution. Then, the mixture was stirred for 6 h under nitrogen and a pale yellow product diimide precipitate was obtained after filtering, washing, and drying under vacuum at 60 °C overnight. Yield: 11.9 g (96%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO): δ 12.10 (s, 2H), 8.62 (s, 4H).

Synthesis of 1,2,3,6,7,8-Hexahydro-2,7-diazapyrene (<bold>2</bold>)

Diimide (2 g, 7.52 mmol) and anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF; 40 mL) was added in a three-neck flask (250 mL) with stirring and refluxing under a nitrogen atmosphere. Then, the suspension was added slowly via the dropping BH3-THF (80 mL, 1 M) solution. The obtained mixture was then refluxed for 60 h. During that time, there was hydrogen evolution and the color changed to orange. The HCl solution (8 mL, 6 M) was added to the mixture and refluxed for quenching the reaction after cooling 0 °C. Caution: at that time, the mixture may foam strongly, so the stirring must be vigorous. The liquid was evaporated, and the residue was cooled to 0 °C. Afterward, potassium carbonate aqueous saturated solution was added for tuning the pH (>10). The solid was added and dried completely under vacuum at 40 °C. The dry solid was extracted with refluxing benzene in a Soxhlet extractor for a week. After this period, the benzene was removed in vacuo to yield 1.22 g (77%) of pure diamine which can be recrystallized from benzene to give off-white powder. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.11 (s, 4H), 4.28 (s, 8H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ 132.90, 127.90, 120.34, 48.90.

Synthesis of DAP (<bold>3</bold>)

A 500 mL round-bottom flask was charged with benzene (250 mL) and then MnO2 (10 g, 115.02 mmol, activated grade, Aldrich) was added. After the addition, the hot solution was filtered after refluxing for 24 h. The filtered MnO2 was dried under vacuum and subjected to a Soxhlet extraction with the benzene solution of the filtrate for 3 days. After removal of the benzene in vacuo, 0.2 g (21%) of pure diazapyrene was obtained as yellow crystals. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.51 (s, 4H), 8.22 (s, 4H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ 144.36, 125.39, 125.20, 124.8.

Synthesis of 1,4,5,8-Naphthalenetetracarboxylic Diimide (1)

1,4,5,8-Naphthalenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (12.5 g, 46.6 mmol) was dissolved in a stirred concentrated ammonium hydroxide (625 mL, 29.5%, w/w) aqueous solution. Then, the mixture was stirred for 6 h under nitrogen and a pale yellow product diimide precipitate was obtained after filtering, washing, and drying under vacuum at 60 °C overnight. Yield: 11.9 g (96%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO): δ 12.10 (s, 2H), 8.62 (s, 4H).

Synthesis of 1,2,3,6,7,8-Hexahydro-2,7-diazapyrene (2)

Diimide (2 g, 7.52 mmol) and anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF; 40 mL) was added in a three-neck flask (250 mL) with stirring and refluxing under a nitrogen atmosphere. Then, the suspension was added slowly via the dropping BH3-THF (80 mL, 1 M) solution. The obtained mixture was then refluxed for 60 h. During that time, there was hydrogen evolution and the color changed to orange. The HCl solution (8 mL, 6 M) was added to the mixture and refluxed for quenching the reaction after cooling 0 °C. Caution: at that time, the mixture may foam strongly, so the stirring must be vigorous. The liquid was evaporated, and the residue was cooled to 0 °C. Afterward, potassium carbonate aqueous saturated solution was added for tuning the pH (>10). The solid was added and dried completely under vacuum at 40 °C. The dry solid was extracted with refluxing benzene in a Soxhlet extractor for a week. After this period, the benzene was removed in vacuo to yield 1.22 g (77%) of pure diamine which can be recrystallized from benzene to give off-white powder. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.11 (s, 4H), 4.28 (s, 8H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ 132.90, 127.90, 120.34, 48.90.

Synthesis of DAP (3)

A 500 mL round-bottom flask was charged with benzene (250 mL) and then MnO2 (10 g, 115.02 mmol, activated grade, Aldrich) was added. After the addition, the hot solution was filtered after refluxing for 24 h. The filtered MnO2 was dried under vacuum and subjected to a Soxhlet extraction with the benzene solution of the filtrate for 3 days. After removal of the benzene in vacuo, 0.2 g (21%) of pure diazapyrene was obtained as yellow crystals. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.51 (s, 4H), 8.22 (s, 4H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ 144.36, 125.39, 125.20, 124.8.

cln_elements.content:
The optical activity properties of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses (a) were further studied at room temperature. The photoluminescence (b and S6) showed that SURchirMOF-4 displayed a similar intense fluorescence with the maximum emissions at 390, 410, and 432 nm when it was excited at 365 nm, which were similar to the UV–vis absorption spectra (Figures S7 and S8). The CD data recorded for SURchirMOFs [Zn2(Dcam)2DAP] n (d-SURchirMOF-4) and [Zn2(Lcam)2DAP] n (l-SURchirMOF-4) were shown in c. The CD spectra showed four negative bands at 243, 271, 335, and 395 nm and two positive bands at 249 and 307 nm for d-SURchirMOF-4 fabricated exclusively with enantiopure Dcam and DAP. Moreover, the enantiomeric pairs show dichroic absorption of an equal in magnitude but opposite signal.

CPL is a unique property used to evaluate the chirality of chiral materials. Recently, scientists have reported a ligand-exchange approach to form a chiral zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) powder for CPL. However, such a ligand-exchange approach usually cannot exchange the ligand completely and the powder form of ZIF is also not convenient in the practical CPL application. Therefore, the in-situ epitaxial growth of MOF thin films for CPL is a promising material for CPL application. Herein, we investigate the CPL of the d- and l-SURMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses. Different handedness CPL signals () could be observed and the relative CPL signals were at ∼330 nm. The results display that the CPL signals of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 were opposite. The corresponding g lum factors (Figure S9) were ∼3 × 10–3 and −8 × 10–3 for d- and l-SURchirMOF-4, respectively.

To further study the chiral recognition of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4, the adsorption performance of enantiomers can be carried out in this work. A gas phase QCM technology has been developed for investigating the enantioselectivity of homochiral MOF thin films, which can monitor mass changes with nanogram by detecting the change of resonance frequency. The d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 thin films were grown on Au-coated QCM sensors. The thickness of d-SURchirMOF-4 was measured by cross-section SEM and was about 320 nm (Figure S10). A pair of enantiomers d- and l-methyl-lactate was selected as the chiral probe molecules for studying their enantioselectivity. The related adsorption amount of d and l-methyl-lactate for d-SURchirMOF-4 and l-SURchirMOF-4 were carried out respectively, which were shown in . The adsorption amount of d- and l-methyl-lactate for d-SURchirMOF-4 was ∼2.08 (M D) and ∼3.54 (M L) μg/cm2, respectively (a). The different adsorption showed an important enantioselective adsorption for one enantiomer methyl-lactate in SURchirMOF-4. When we applied the equation “ee % = (M L – M D)/(M D + M L) × 100” for analyzing the enantioselectivity, the enantioselectivity ee % of SURchirMOF-4 for methyl-lactate was found to be 26%. With the same measurement, the probe enantiomers of d/l-methyl-lactate were used for studying the enantioselective adsorption of l-SURchirMOF-4. The recorded data (b) showed that the adsorption amounts of d- and l-methyl-lactate were ∼3.62 (M D) and ∼2.02 (M L) μg/cm2 for l-SURchirMOF-4, respectively. The related enantioselectivity ee % was 28% after using the same equation, which was the opposite enantioselective adsorption of d-SURchirMOF-4.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The optical activity properties of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses (a) were further studied at room temperature. The photoluminescence (b and S6) showed that SURchirMOF-4 displayed a similar intense fluorescence with the maximum emissions at 390, 410, and 432 nm when it was excited at 365 nm, which were similar to the UV-vis absorption spectra (Figures S7 and S8). The CD data recorded for SURchirMOFs [Zn2(Dcam)2DAP] n  (d-SURchirMOF-4) and [Zn2(Lcam)2DAP] n  (l-SURchirMOF-4) were shown in c. The CD spectra showed four negative bands at 243, 271, 335, and 395 nm and two positive bands at 249 and 307 nm for d-SURchirMOF-4 fabricated exclusively with enantiopure Dcam and DAP. Moreover, the enantiomeric pairs show dichroic absorption of an equal in magnitude but opposite signal.

CPL is a unique property used to evaluate the chirality of chiral materials. Recently, scientists have reported a ligand-exchange approach to form a chiral zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF) powder for CPL. However, such a ligand-exchange approach usually cannot exchange the ligand completely and the powder form of ZIF is also not convenient in the practical CPL application. Therefore, the in-situ epitaxial growth of MOF thin films for CPL is a promising material for CPL application. Herein, we investigate the CPL of the d- and l-SURMOF-4 grown on quartz glasses. Different handedness CPL signals () could be observed and the relative CPL signals were at ~330 nm. The results display that the CPL signals of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 were opposite. The corresponding g lum factors (Figure S9) were ~3 × 10-3 and -8 × 10-3 for d- and l-SURchirMOF-4, respectively.

To further study the chiral recognition of d- and l-SURchirMOF-4, the adsorption performance of enantiomers can be carried out in this work. A gas phase QCM technology has been developed for investigating the enantioselectivity of homochiral MOF thin films, which can monitor mass changes with nanogram by detecting the change of resonance frequency. The d- and l-SURchirMOF-4 thin films were grown on Au-coated QCM sensors. The thickness of d-SURchirMOF-4 was measured by cross-section SEM and was about 320 nm (Figure S10). A pair of enantiomers d- and l-methyl-lactate was selected as the chiral probe molecules for studying their enantioselectivity. The related adsorption amount of d and l-methyl-lactate for d-SURchirMOF-4 and l-SURchirMOF-4 were carried out respectively, which were shown in . The adsorption amount of d- and l-methyl-lactate for d-SURchirMOF-4 was ~2.08 (M D) and ~3.54 (M L) μg/cm2, respectively (a). The different adsorption showed an important enantioselective adsorption for one enantiomer methyl-lactate in SURchirMOF-4. When we applied the equation "ee % = (M L - M D)/(M D + M L) × 100" for analyzing the enantioselectivity, the enantioselectivity ee % of SURchirMOF-4 for methyl-lactate was found to be 26%. With the same measurement, the probe enantiomers of d/l-methyl-lactate were used for studying the enantioselective adsorption of l-SURchirMOF-4. The recorded data (b) showed that the adsorption amounts of d- and l-methyl-lactate were ~3.62 (M D) and ~2.02 (M L) μg/cm2 for l-SURchirMOF-4, respectively. The related enantioselectivity ee % was 28% after using the same equation, which was the opposite enantioselective adsorption of d-SURchirMOF-4.
